Entries.default: "What all do you write in those reports of yours, Maia? Did you detail the Watcher? What about me?"
"I may have told the company one or two choice details about you."
"For real? You thought me worth noting in your politic papers? Heh, maybe I'll make my temple proud yet."
"So you're... flattered? Interesting. Guess I'll add that to the next report."
"Ishi's crap is harder to get out of leather than tar! This is the second time he's gotten my boots."
"It's a phase. He's just trying to cozy up to you, firefly."
"Well, I was sneaking him some extra seeds..."
"Can you make him target who he poops on? 'Cause I got someone in mind..."
"This sounds like a story. Tell. Me. Everything."
"Ishi keeps hopping in your direction, firefly. What have you been feeding him?"
"No more than a handful... or few... of murkberries. I swear."
"How much of Eora have you actually visited? Which lands - no, wait - what was the strangest thing you ever saw?"
"Found an island with a pillar of adra carved into a giant foot."
"Gaun, what a thrill! You're so well-traveled, it's amazing. But don't you ever miss home? What about your loved ones?"
"Aside from my family, anyone special to me is already here, firefly."
"Well, that's... You see, I... I mean, same for me."
"Tell me something you learned on the farm, Xoti."
"Dried dung's good for starting fires."
"Huh... Well, this has been an education."
"...so the pirates took us for merchants and fell right into our trap."
"That sure sounds dangerous... and fun as Hel."
"The first time Uncle Angbert trained me with the lantern, I set a whole row of murkberry stalks on fire."
"You didn't!"
"I did. The whole house came running and hollering. You should've seen my grandma, beating at the stalks with a shovel. 'Course she came after me next."
"Not so much grows in Rauatai. With a little luck, I'll have a farm story of my own some day."
"I don't believe it. A copper pand, from 400 yards? You're pulling my leg."
"It's easy, I'll show you. Hold this up in the air and stand very still."
"It's not that I don't have faith, but maybe Pallegina ought to stand in, instead."
"When this tour of duty is over, I'm buying my own ship. Something small and fast."
"Oh. I guess you'll be off then... sailing the high seas, chasing some grand adventure, all by your lonesome...?"
"And then you vomited right in my face."
"Aheh... sorry about that! Was it chunky or creamy?"
"I think it was a shepherd's pie, so... chunky."
"For a girl off the farm, you have got some colorful nightmares, Xoti."
"Watcher, I wanted to ask you about Maia - if you don't mind."
"What about her?"
"Maybe later."

"Gods, where should I even start? Well, for one, I think we get along real swimmingly. Too swimmingly."

She tunnels a hand through her hair, disheveling it.
"Right. I'll do what I can to sort it out on my own and let you know how it works out."
"It's the strangest thing. But sometimes when she's nearby... my heart gets to lurching in my chest like some wounded thing. And my stomach twists up."
"Especially when she kills someone or she laughs."
"It sounds like you've developed a crush."
"How does Maia feel about you?"
"No, no. That can't be right. She's not a..." Her face screws up as she seriously considers it.
"Person of the cloth."

"I don't rightly know. Should I ask her? 'Cause I think maybe I should ask her. But no -"

She gives her head a sharp shake.
"Is that all you wanted to tell me?"

"Yeah, I reckon it is. Thanks for hearing me out."

Dark eyes narrowed, Xoti bites her lip as if to keep from saying more - maybe something she'd regret.
"Is that really a problem for you?"
"So put an end to the relationship, now, before anyone gets hurt."
"My high priestess would say it ought to be. But no, for me... I suppose it's not."

"But what do I do? How do I proceed? Specifically."

A frown tugs at Xoti's worry-nibbled lips, and she tilts her head as if waiting for you to hand her the answer she seeks.
"If you'll pardon me, I won't bother you with it again."
"That might make it weird between us. Don't you think?"
"You'll never know if you don't ask."
"You've given me a lot to consider. I'll... think on it. And I thank you for the advice."
"Tell her bluntly that you'd like to be romantically involved."
"Hint at your interest. See if she responds positively."
"Woo her. Shower her with gifts and compliments."
"Take the bull by the horns. So to speak. I like it."
"Lay the bait without scaring her off. It may require more finesse than I've got, but it's a sound strategy."
"She's usually the one bringing trinkets back for me. I think you've got the way of it - might be she'd like a gift for a change."
"Wish me luck, Watcher. 'Cause I'm sure going to need it." She bites back a grin.
"Hey, captain. I've got a... well, a something on my mind. Could use a second opinion is all."
"What seems to be the problem, Maia?"
"Mutiny? Is it mutiny?"
"You probably noticed that Xoti and I have been getting awfully cozy." Maia plants her hand on her hip and raises a brow.
"No! I mean, not yet... I mean, not ever!" Bewildered, Maia shakes her head and starts again.
"She's dangerous, and that thrills you."
"What do you mean, Watcher? How she's a sharpshooter? Or is it 'cause she's so well-traveled and knows all the ways of the world?"
"If she had to, I think she would."
"Stay away from her. It's for your own good."
"You don't think she'd hurt me or you, would she?"
"I think she cares for you... as much as she's able."
"Probably, Maia views you as a friend - and nothing more."
"R-right. Of course. I didn't mean to - I mean, of course, I know we're friends. Just friends."
"Do you?"
"Good Gaun, no! And if you do, why'd you let her along with us? Surely, you ought to trust her, as much as I do."

"Maia may not admit it, but she loves her family and Ishiza, too. She's not unfeeling, you know."

Her brows draw together, a dark slash of emotion.
Xoti shakes her head and runs her tongue over her bottom lip, clearly having none of it.
"Who wouldn't do what they had to, if forced into it? But I'll tell you this - she wouldn't HAVE to hurt me. I'd gladly take a wound to protect any of us."
"Except for maybe Pallegina." She shrugs.
Eyes half-mast, she gnaws at her bottom lip, slowly nods.

"Not only is she not a Gaunite, but - well, she doesn't regularly regard any god, aside from nursing a healthy respect for Ondra. We'd be a terrible match, surely."

But at the mention of them together, Xoti lopsidedly grins, a dreamy expression softening the lines of her face.
"For Maia, I can look past it."
"Step one - stop being such a darned chicken. Fair enough."
"What do you mean, Watcher? You think she's hardhearted? 'Cause she's so stoic? Or is it on account of her being a professional killer?"
"Maybe it's not too late." She snorts.
"Show her your -"

"Watcher, if the next word out of your mouth happens to be 'charms,' I'm going to show you my right fist."

Despite the threat, Xoti grins good-naturedly.
"What do you mean, Watcher? You think she's hardhearted? 'Cause she's served on a lot of ships? 'Cause she's moved on from more than a few people?"
"I know it's a risk - that maybe one day, she'll leave me in her wake, too." She sighs, glances briefly at her feet.
"Maia, hon? I, uhm - well, there's this thing I've been meaning to tell you... for a while now."
"What, I got something on my face?"
"No! It's just that you're really swell, is all. And I thought, you know, you should know it."
"Swell, huh? You're looking pretty flushed for 'swell,' firefly."
"Look, all I'm saying is that any kith would be lucky to know you like that. Real lucky. Like blessed by the gods lucky."
"Don't sell yourself short, firefly. I'm sure you learned a thing or two on the farm."
"Not near so much as I'd like. But I mean, I could... show you... under the light of the moon?"
"Well, don't just stare at it, Maia. Take it."
"A cleaning kit for my rifle! Xoti, this has everything! How much do I owe you?"
"What? No, hon, it's meant to be a present."
"Gosh, firefly. Here you are granting wishes and I'm empty-handed."
"Am I? 'Cause I mean... That is... You're more than swell, you're..."
"Let's you and me talk somewhere cool over a cup of something warm."
"The way your eyes reflect the light of that spooky lantern... Well, it gets a girl's attention, is all."
"Good Gaun, I'm sorry! H-here, let me dim the light."
"Hey, hey... calm down, firefly. Bet you didn't know I had my eye on you."
"Well. Every captain needs her first mate."
"I mean... Since you mentioned it... one thing might come to mind..."
"Oh, this ought to be good. How's this?"
"On second thought... let's practice later. I don't like this breeze."
"I thought I'd miss my brethren more... but having someone who understands me. It's a surprising relief."
"I thought, culturally, Readcerans only entered into pairings that can produce viable offspring...?"
"Yeah, and your point is...?" Expression souring, she crosses her arms over her chest and hitches out a hip.
"I've delivered enough calves, kids, piglets, and my own baby siblings to know which bits go where, Watcher."
"Not interested."
"Well... I'm glad we had this little chat, then." Maia shrugs, frowning in your direction.
"Well, she made a confession to me. Mixture of feelings, intentions, and... other stuff."
"Go on."
"You mean like she confessed to a murder?"
"Ha. Not exactly. Though I think she's fixing to kill a craving of mine."

"Xoti's a lot like her lantern - you can see straight through, but she's got a flame inside that never goes out. 

"I... like that about her."
"But it's been years since I was... landlocked with someone. I'm worried about cracking those glass windows of hers. I don't want to risk her flame going out."
"I guess life is just tossing yourself in someone's direction and hoping they catch you on the first try." Sighing, Maia gestures off into the distance.
"She's been real... complimentary, and we had ourselves a moment below deck." Maia's gaze wanders elsewhere, showing only the hint of a smile.
"She gave me a real thoughtful present - brushes, oils, and replacement parts for my rifle." Grinning, Maia scratches behind her neck.
"Give her a little credit. She's tougher than she looks."
"Since she's pursuing you, why not let her set the pace of things?"
"So let her down nicely. Just tell her it's not the time to get involved."
"Heh. Nothing I didn't already know, but she put a nice twist on it."
"Go on."
"What, did she teach you a new game?"
"When she's around, it's like I've been standing in a crow's nest for too long and finally spotted a hint of land."
"At first I didn't know if she was trying to tell me something. Later we were chatting below deck, and we had ourselves a moment."
"Go on."
"What, is she interested in guns now?"
"I want to see what my firefly can do, and I know she's keen on showing me." Maia glances away with a hint of apprehension.
"Between her eyes and that voice, Xoti's got enough weapons at her disposal."
"You're right about that. Could be that I'm the one who needs to toughen up for a change." Maia folds her arms and sighs.
"Hand over the reins, so to speak? That's a fair and... refreshing point."
"I don't want to sound like I'm not interested. Far from it. It's just that these things usually happen as a matter of necessity."
"When you're on a month long voyage and the need takes over, you learn to think of privacy, options, and planning as luxuries."
"What you describe with Xoti sounds different."
"So take some time to indulge yourselves. That's an order, soldier."
"If you're not ready for this, no one's holding a sickle to your neck."
"That's what has me worried. It's... well, it's a new kind of vulnerable."
"Appreciate you taking the time to hear me out, captain."
"There's not a thing in the world that could make me more ready... except Xoti's smile, I think."
"I don't think Xoti's up to it. Maybe once she's more seasoned."
Taking in a deep breath, Maia nods to herself - a slow, reluctant motion.
"I guess Xoti needs some space to figure herself out. Suppose me getting involved would only distract her."
"Hate to break her heart, but if there's a responsible way to go about it... damn, I owe her that much." Maia shrugs, focusing her attention far away.
"Hey Xoti. Remember I told you about that spot on the small of my back I can't reach?"
"I like how you spin a yarn, firefly. The way it gets you all swept up and excited."
"Hey, Maia! What do you say, we share a drink together?"
"I might... yeah."
"Was wondering if you could give it a scratch later when we're alone."
"Oh... sure. I reckon, I... Wait, you don't mean...?"
"Do I need Ishi to spell it out for you, firefly?"
"No. No, I think I'm finally hearing what you're saying, captain."
"Why, thank you, Maia! I usually get to feeling like I annoy people, but you keep asking for more farm stories, so..."
"I could listen all night, you know."
"We should definitely get together tonight by the campfire! I've been meaning to tell you about that time I rode a bull right over a hay bale."
"Aye, captain!" Maia snaps to a sharp salute, though she can't wipe the smile from her face.
"I'm not gonna dive into figuring out why, but hearing that from an officer and not a friend does something for me."
"That's awfully sweet of you to invite me. I'll bring the wine."
"Alcohol? Why would we need...? Oh. Oooh. Right... of course!"
"Another time. I'm trying to keep my inhibitions inhibited at the moment."
"That's all right. That's fine. Then... how about that card game you were going to teach me?"
"Ah... maybe later, Xoti."
"Do we... do you want to talk about something?"
"I don't... yeah, yeah I guess we should."
"Heh... you keep doing that, he's gonna follow you all the way home to Readceras."
"To meet my kin? Now wouldn't that be a tribulation."
"I know I'd make the journey for less than a few murkberries."
"What?"
"The poetry bug didn't hit me like it hit Kana, all right?" Maia scratches the back of her neck and sighs.
"Xoti's real sweet, but she's young and... and doesn't have the same scar tissue some of us carry around like it's nothing."
"I'm worried that I'll hurt her, take away that sunny outlook, and we'll both hate me for it."
"You're concerned for her. I take that as encouragement, Maia."
"I want to encourage this. Maybe I'm out of practice. Maybe I'm just scared."
"I really... want to deserve her. To treat her right. I know without asking that she wants the same."
"You already deserve her. She chose you, so go get her already."
"Am I overthinking this? I'm overthinking this." Maia nurses her brow, sighing pleasantly.
"Do we need to have the Birds and the Bees talk, Xoti?"
"Clearly, this doesn't concern you."

"It does but not how you think. I'm stubborn, yeah. But I'm not entirely ignorant."

She rubs her nose with dry-skinned and muddy knuckles.
"But that's not who I am. And I can't say whether it's who I'll ever want to be. I am a reaper of Gaun. My purpose isn't to farm, it's to shepherd the souls of the dead, Watcher."
"Long term, you're right. My ma expected me to grow into a gods-fearing Bringer of the Light who'd raise enough farmhands to run the family homestead."

"Now, you might think I can do both. Maybe some day, I will. Or maybe I won't ever. But that's for me and my god to decide."

She sighs, shoulders drooping.
"Don't get offended, I was just curious."
"All right." She shrugs, dropping her arms to her sides.
"Then I'm simply curious as to why you care."
"I'm just surprised you're different."
"Just... forget it."
"Surely. I will if you will, Watcher."
"My whole life folks keep complaining 'cause I'm different." Scratching an ear, she shrugs again.
"Long as I please my god, what do I care if others like me or not?"
"I just think... why's it got to matter until then?"
"I had other questions."
"Let's be off."
"Maia, I sure missed you while you were gone."
"Feeling's mutual, firefly. I promise I won't stray far from your light again."
"Spar with me tonight, Maia, hon? I know you don't like close combat, but I got to burn off some of this restlessness."
"Name the time and place. Ishi, no peeking this time."
"I had a dream about me and you, Maia. It was... real nice."
"Ah, so that explains all the tossing and turning last night."
"Well, I was thinking we could maybe try some of it, tonight? If you'd like?"
"So what're we doing once this is all over? I was thinking I'd return to my temple, but that was before... you know."
"If I could think that far ahead, I'd be the queen of the Deadfire by now."
"But you may not have a choice on account of your mission, right? What if next time... You don't come back again?"
"How's about you let me do the worrying for the both of us?"
"What? No, I mean I'm craving a fight something fierce. Like bruised knuckles and busted lips."
"Oh. Guess my mind went wandering somewhere else."
"Hope it was better than the vomit dream."
"Uh... Let's just say I felt this dream down to my bones."
"I'll agree to anything if you promise to quit stealing all the blankets."
"I don't what'll happen, but I think we'll both weather it if we stay close. Sound all right to you?"
"I like that idea, yeah. You want me close, I'll be your second shadow."
"Course we can spar, firefly. Don't hold anything back."
"We'll take the future together, one day at a time."
